text: GRAHAM sits in the passenger seat of a sedan that lies sk on the gravel shoulder, red lights playing on the passeng side window. He's black, thirties, staring off, either da or grappling with a very deep thought. GRAHAM (continuing) We're always behind metal and glass. Think we miss that touch so much, we crash into each other just to feel something. He looks to the driver, RIA, American-born Hispanic, thir heart racing, breathing hard, but watching Graham with re concern. A MOTORCYCLE COP appears at her open window.
You two all right?
I think he mighta hit his head.
You don't think that's true?
Stay in your car. The officer moves off. (CONTINUED)

Graham, we were rear-ended. We spun around twice. Somewhere in there one of us lost our frame of reference. I'm gonna go look for it. She climbs out. Graham looks off through his side window. The reflections from emergency lights and flares play on face; too many lights for a simple traffic accident.

Ria walks toward the Volvo that just rear-ended them. Its driver, KIM LEE, an agitated Korean woman, screams at the motorcycle cop in Korean. Burning flares squeeze traffic down to one lane, a cop herds the cars into line.
Calm down, ma'am!
I am calm!
I need to see your registration and insurance.
Why? Not my fault! Her fault! She do this!
(approaching) I do this?
Ma'am, wait in your vehicle.
Stop in middle of street! Mexicans! No know how to drive! She blake too fast!
I "blake" too fast?? Oh, sorry, you no see my "blake lights?"
Ma-am-- (CONTINUED)
(to Kim Lee) I blake when I see long line cars stop in front of me. You see over steering wheel, maybe you blake, too.
(to Ria) Ma'am--
Crazy Mexican! I call immigration on you! Look you do my car!
(to cop) Can you just write in your report how shocked I am to have been hit by an Asian driver?
Ma'am--
(flashing badge) It's not Ma'am, it's Detective.
Oh, Christ.
He pops the flashing red light onto the dash and steps ou the car.
Graham folds his collar against the cold and crosses the dark street that cuts through this patch of oil fields in the center of Inglewood. The argument rages in the background:

No care you cop, wanna see insurance! Stupid wetback blake my car! (etc.) Graham steps toward a swarm of activity that has nothing do with the collision that just occurred -- three police cars, a coroner's vehicle and crime scene tape tells us (CONTINUED)
something nasty happened down in the long grass of the irrigation ditch. He dips under the crime scene tape.
a bored-looking man lighting a cigarette and staring at t ditch. Graham steps up and watches with him.
You okay?
Freezing.
Heard it might snow.
Get outta here.
That's what I heard.
You got a smoke?
(blowing out smoke) Quit.

Me, too. Carr hands Graham a cigarette. He can't help glancing at Ria's escalating battle. He looks to Graham, the question implied. Graham gives him a shrug: "don't go there." Carr understands completely.
What have you got? A tech passes, heading into the crime scene.
Dead kid. Graham notices something odd and walks down into the gull
You touch anything and it's yours. He kneels to inspect a piece of evidence hidden in the ta weeds. A feeling starts to creep over him. (CONTINUED)
Not a good feeling. As he looks up we FADE TO BLACK. Supe TODAY.
The handgun slides onto the counter. The hand belongs to DIRK, the impatient salesman.
You get one free box of ammunition, what kind you want? Widen to see we're --
FARHAD, Iranian, 50s, looks at the handgun and turns to h daughter DORRI, 25, who wears a blue suit and a bad mood.
(in Farsi) What did he say "ammunition"?
(in Farsi) He asked what kind of bullets you want.
(in Farsi) The kind that fit in the gun!
(in Farsi) There's more than one type.
(in Farsi) How do I know? I don't know anything about bullets.
(in Farsi) Which is a really good reason not to be buying a gun. (CONTINUED)
(in Farsi) You don't use that tone of voice with me.
Yo, Osama, plan the Jihad on your own time; what do you want?
(in Farsi) What is he saying about Jihad? (to Dirk, in English:) Are you making insults at me?
Am I making insults at you?? That's the closest you get to English?
I am American citizen--!
(here it comes) --Oh, God.
--I have rights like you! I have right to buy gun! Dirk pulls the gun back to his side of the counter.
Not from my store, you don't. Dirk nods toward the Security Guard, who heads this way. Dorri sees him coming.
Go wait in the car, Dad.
(to Dirk) You are ignorant man!
Yeah, I'm ignorant; you're liberating my country and I'm flying 747s into your mud huts and incinerating your friends. Get the fuck out of my store. (CONTINUED)
(taking his arm) You don't touch! This man Let's go. cheats me!
(to Farhad) Do you want to get arrested? Go wait in the car, Dad! Farhad storms out, the security guard following. Dorri lo the salesman dead in the eye:
You can give me the gun or give me the money back, and I'm really hoping for the money. Dirk looks Dorri up and down, gives her a lecherous smile and slides the gun back across the counter.
And what kind of ammunition do you want?
Whatever fits.

Oh, we got a lot of things that fit. We got long colts, short colts, ball heads, flat-nose, hollow points, wad cutters and a dozen more that all fit in the same size hole, just depends how big a "bang" you can handle.
(pointing) I'll take the ones in the red box.
(looks; looks back) ...-Do you know what those are?
Can I have them? He takes the box with a snort and places it on the counte with the gun. Dorri snatches them up and exits.  3/18/04 8.
A couple opens the door and enters a moderately priced It restaurant; call the guy ALLAN, call his date angry.

No, please tell me: what "sin" did I commit this time? And we lose them as ANTHONY flies out the door, PETER jus one step behind him. They're in their early twenties, you hip, well-dressed black men, friends since third grade. They button their jackets as they head down the sidewalk.
You see any white people in there waiting an hour and thirty two minutes for a plate of spaghetti? Huh? And how many cups of coffee did we get?
You don't drink coffee and I didn't want any.
That woman poured cup after cup to every white person around us. Did she even ask you if you wanted any?
We didn't get any coffee that you didn't want and I didn't order, and this is evidence of racial discrimination? Did you happen to notice our waitress was black?

And black women don't think in stereotypes? When's the last time you met one who didn't think she knew everything about your lazy ass before you even opened your mouth? That waitress sized us up in two seconds. We're black and "black people don't tip" so she wasn't gonna waste her time; someone like that, nothing you can do to change their mind. (CONTINUED)
So how much you leave her? The angry girl runs past them.
You expect me to pay for that kinda service?? Peter laughs; Anthony doesn't. Allan runs by chasing his date.
...What? What? Hey, come on! I'm sorry.

Nothing, nothing. The camera whips around with Allan. We lose him as he cut across the street, and find RICK & JEAN CABOT, white, ear 40s, step out of the Blockbuster and head for their car. Jean pulls her jacket closed as they walk.
You're seriously jealous of Karen??
Hardly. I'd just like to see you get through a meal without calling her, or someone else at your office.
(re: cell phone) See this? Off. No more calls tonight . Jean notices Anthony and Peter and takes Rick's arm.
Ten bucks says she calls on the car phone.
You see what that woman just did?
She's cold, man. (CONTINUED)
She got colder soon as she saw us.
--Here it comes.

Look around! You couldn't find a whiter, safer or better lit part of this city. But this white woman sees two black guys, who look like UCLA students, strolling down the sidewalk and her reaction is blind fear. I mean, look at us! Are we dressed like gangbangers? Do we look threatening? No. Fact, if anybody should be scared, it's us: the only two black faces surrounded by a sea of over-caffeinated white people, patrolled by the trigger- happy LAPD. So, why aren't we scared?
Because we have guns?
You could be right. Both men reach into their clothing and come out with Satu night specials. They rush toward Rick's black Navigator.
Away from the car! Oh my God! Oh my God! Away from the car! Rick!
Gimme the keys! Gimme Don't shoot, just don't the keys! Shut up and shoot. give me the keys!
Walk away! Walk away! Turn around and walk!
Anthony hops into the driver's seat, screaming for Peter:
Get in! Get in! (CONTINUED)
Unlock the door! Anthony does. Peter hops in as Anthony sparks the ignitio To Peter's surprise Anthony hops back out...
..-.and he aims his gun at Rick and Jean's back.
Stop!! They freeze. Anthony runs up, grabs the DVD.
Anthony drops into the seat and tosses the DVD at Peter.

(reading label) Haven't seen it. Anthony shifts into first and screams out of there. Peter digs into his pocket and pulls out a plastic St. Christop statuette. He licks the suction cup and sticks it on the dashboard.
No! No! Take that voodoo-ass thing off there right now! Look at the marks it makes!
You're calling St. Christopher voodoo? Man's the patron saint of travelers.
God talk to you, did he? What did he say? "Go forth my son and leave big, slobbery suction rings on every dashboard you find??" Why the hell do you do that?
Look at the way you drive, then ask me again!  3/18/04 12.

A squad car wipes, revealing a sea of flashing red lights A Mercedes sits in middle of it all, doors open, body on ground beside it. Uniformed cops stand around pretending they are actually doing something. One of them leads us t
who walk from their unmarked sedan, accompanied by a unif cop, OFFICER JOHNSON.
Ford pickup and Mercedes driving North on Hill. The pickup cuts in front. Driver of the Mercedes gets pissed, pulls a gun -- he doesn't realize the guy in the pickup is a cop coming off shift.
That the cop? He nods toward a tall man, long stringy hair, sipping a c and leaning against a squad car, chatting with two unifor
Yeah. Name is Conklin. He's a Narc out of Wilshire. You want to talk to him?
Not yet.
Mercedes takes a shot at him. Detective Conklin returns fire, one shot. Mercedes hits the wall, driver opens the door and falls out dead.
I got the Mercedes. Ria splits off toward the Mercedes.
(ve: Conklin) Looks pretty relaxed for having shot a man. (CONTINUED)
Coming up on Conklin's Ford pickup:
He says he kept trying to drive away but the Mercedes kept pulling up next to him, the gun. Shot back Graham stoops to see a bullet
Anyone see who shot
They just heard two screaming, waving in self-defense. hole in the driver's door. first?
bangs.
Find me a witness. Graham splits off and arrives examines the body of the dead in his head. A pearl handled at the Mercedes, where Ria black driver, a bullet wound revolver lies on the floor.
Nice gun.

One bullet fired. The car is registered to Cindy Bradley. That's not his name. His name is William Lewis. (hands him a wallet) It was under the front seat. Graham opens the wallet, revealing a Detective's Badge.
(looking at dead cop's business card) Hollywood Division. Graham lets out a low whistle, then throws a look to Conk

Looks like Detective Conklin shot himself the wrong nigga. As Graham stands we cut to:  3/18/04 14. 10 INT. CARNEY'S - STUDIO CITY -- NIGHT 10° Crowded with patrons who order hot drinks. We SLIDE PAST two Korean businessmen. CHOI JIN GUIH, late 40's, dressed well, sits across the table from the younger looking PARK Park rips a check out of his checkbook, hands it to Choi.
How soon can I have them? Choi folds the check and stuffs it in his wallet.
Tonight. I'm picking them up right now. Good doing business with you. Choi shakes Park's hand and heads out the back door.
I keep telling you he's in pain. He can't sleep. Choi passes OFFICER RYAN on the pay phone by the door. He white, in uniform, and angry.
(over phone) And I told you the clinic is only open after hours for emergencies--
--This is an emergency--
SHANIQUA, a very tired black administrator is on the othe end of the line.

--Mr. Ryan, your father has been to the clinic three times in the last month. He's being treated for a urinary tract infection that is by no means an emergency. If you have any more questions about your HMO plan, you can make an appointment to come in from ten to four, Monday through Friday. (CONTINUED)
What does my father do about sleeping tonight?
I don't know. I'm not a doctor.
I want to speak to your supervisor.
I am my supervisor.
What's your name?
Shaniqua Johnson.
Big fucking surprise that is. Ryan hears the click and hangs up, exits...
.-approaches his partner TOM HANSEN, who stirs his

Call any big company with a problem; why is the person you have to deal with guaranteed to be black and stupid? Why? Because corporations are smart. They actually seek out the stupidest fucking black people they can find. They want us to get so frustrated that we'll go away and they won't have to spend their fucking money. (walking off) Genius. Hansen stirs some more. As RYAN exits to the parking lot white panel van stops at the sidewalk, CHOI driving.
As Ryan and Hansen climb in they hear: (CONTINUED)
Black late model Navigator, California plate: 4PCI315.
A black Navigator passes, a 40ish black man at the wheel.
Suspects are two black males, approximately 20 years of age, armed and dangerous.
Pulls out to follow.
It's not it. (no response) It's not the vehicle. The plates don't match, the driver's in his forties, and nobody jacks a car and takes it to Studio City. Ryan hits the flashers.

A woman pops up in the passenger seat. She may have been napping in the driver's lap, or she may have been doing something else. She throws a look back at the cop car. Caught in the headlights her face looks chalk white.
Sees her face and bumps the siren.
They were doing something.

The Navigator pulls to a stop under a street lamp, the sq car pulls up behind. Ryan steps out. Hansen clearly doesn like this; nonetheless, he steps out and assumes the back position. Ryan approaches the window, unsnapping his hols
Keep your hands in plain sight. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
I need to see your license and registration. Behind the wheel, CAMERON THAYER, 40ish, black, tucks his shirt back into his tuxedo pants and digs out his wallet.
No problem. Ryan looks to the passenger reapplying her lipstick: CHRI THAYER, strikingly beautiful, light-skinned black woman i cocktail dress. She may have had a bit too much to drink.
Evening.
(suppressing a smile) How are you tonight, officer?
I need to reach into the glove compartment to get the registration.
Do it slowly, please. Ryan lays his hand on his Glock as Cameron reaches over t get his papers. Ryan's flashlight beam glides from the gl compartment to Christine's breasts, then up to her face.
Here you go. He slowly hands the documents to Ryan.
Stay in the vehicle, please. He walks back to the squad car and hands the license and registration to Hansen and returns to the Navigator.
Step onto the sidewalk, please, sir.
I haven't been drinking. (CONTINUED)
Then we shouldn't have a problem.
He doesn't drink. He's a Buddhist for Christ's sake.
It's okay, Christine.
runs the license, keeping his eye on Cameron as he steps around to the sidewalk.
(to Cameron) Stand on your right foot and touch your nose with the index finger of your left hand. As Cameron does...
steps out of the car.
I told you he doesn't drink.
Ma'am, I'm only going to tell you one time to wait in the vehicle.
"Matam??"
Get in the car, Christine.
Don't you "Matam" me, I'm not your fucking mammy. Ryan motions for his partner to join him as...
Both of you, turn around, hands on your head, interlock your fingers. (CONTINUED)
Officer, we're a block from home --
Don't talk to me, put your hands on your head and interlock your fingers.
(approaching) I'm a television director, What have we got? my wife and I just came back from an awards dinner-- Ryan grabs Cameron's wrist and slams him up against the truck...
What did I just tell you? ...and kicks his feet out. Cam puts his hands on his head
Get your hands off him!
(to Hansen) Pat him down. (to Christine) Put your hands on your head, ma'am. Hansen reluctantly pats Cameron down.
Do what he says.
(to Cameron) Fuck you! (to Ryan) And you keep your filthy fuckin' hands off me! Ryan takes her wrist and twists her into the car face fir kicking her feet out from under her.
Ow! You fucking pig!
Christine, stop talking. (CONTINUED)
That's quite a mouth you have. (to Cameron) Course, you know that.
Fuck you. That's why you're doing this, isn't it? You thought you saw a white woman blowing a black man and that just drove your little cracker ass crazy!
Christine, shut your goddamn mouth!
I'd listen to your husband, Ma'am. Ryan runs his hands up the sides of her torso...
Do you have any guns or knives on you, anything I'm going to get stuck with?
I'm wearing a cocktail dress, what do you think?

You'd be surprised the places I've found weapons. He slides his hands over the sides of her breasts. pretends not to see, as he quickly frisks Cameron. turns her head so she catches her husband's eyes.
Clean. But Ryan is nowhere near finished.
(to Cameron) So, what do you think we should do about this, Mr. Thayer? Ryan squats and runs his hands down to her ankles... (CONTINUED)
Hansen Christine 19  19 3/18/04 21.
My partner and I just witnessed your wife performing fellatio on you while you were operating a motor vehicle. Now his hands start up the inside of her calves.
That's reckless endangerment... Hansen looks away, knowing this is bullshit.

...which is a felony. Then we could charge your wife here with lewd conduct and performing a sexual act in public. His hands reach up her thighs into her dress and linger t Christine looks away from her husband, her rage replaced humiliation.
Now, you say you're a block from home. We can use our discretion, let you go with a warning. Or we can cuff you and put you in the back of the car. Ryan removes his hands.
What do you think we should do?
We're...sorry. We'd appreciate it if you'd...just give us a warning.
(to Hansen) Man's apologizing, Tommy. I think we can let them go, don't you?
Yeah. Ryan looks into Christine's face, daring her to say anyth She doesn't. (CONTINUED)
Fine. You can go.
...Thank you.
No problem. (walking away) You folks drive safe now. Christine climbs into the passenger seat as Cameron circl the vehicle.
Cameron gets in the driver's seat, sees Christine is shak Puts his hand on hers. She pulls it away. Cameron starts the car and drives off.
watches them go. A decision made, he drops into his seat and closes the car door.
SHEREEN, Farhad's wife, repeatedly slams the back door. Unlike her daughter, she wears traditional dress.
It won't close. FARHAD stands with Dorri as she loads the gun from the am box.
Pull it hard. She keeps trying as....
(to Dorri) I can do that! She snaps the cylinder in place.
You couldn't even get it open. (CONTINUED)
(in Farsi) You have no respect for your father anymore? Give me the gun.

There. Now you can shoot anybody you want. She hands him the gun and ammo. He turns on his heel and exits. Dorri follows him into THE FRONT OF THE STORE. Far pops open a hidden drawer under the cash register and pla the gun and ammo in it.
That man could have killed your mother. You think I should let crazy people do what they want to us? Shereen comes out from the back room.
Farhad, it won't close. Farhad disappears into the back room.
(to Dorri) You should be at work. Dorri turns and exits.
The stolen black Navigator screams around the corner into barren strip of Los Angles, hip-hop blaring from its speakers.
No, you want to listen to music of the Oppressor, you go right ahead.
How in the lunacy of your mind is Hip-Hop "music of the Oppressor??" (CONTINUED)

Listen to it! Nigga-this, nigga that; you think white people walk around calling each other honkies?? "Hey, Honky, how's business?" "Goin! great, Cracker, we're diversifying." Peter punches the radio, a country western singer wails.
This better? You like this? Man's singing about lynchin' a nigga.
And you think there's a difference?
(singing) "Gonna buy me a rope, and lynch me a niggaaaaaaa..."
You got no idea where Hip-Hop comes from, do you?
Almost deserted; they fly past small factories and busine closed for the night. Only one vehicle in sight, a panel van parked way up ahead on this side of the street.

Back in the sixties we (wailing and twanging) had smart, articulate "I'd shoot him dead first, black men. Huey Newton, but I done broke my Bobby Seale, Eldridge triggaaaaaaaaaa...... Cleaver, Fred Hampton; Gonna get out my sheet, these brothers were put my hood on my heaaaad... speaking out and people were listening. A Korean man steps out from in front of the van, stops at the driver's door, searching his pockets. (CONTINUED)

The FBI said: "Oh, we "Gonna string him up good, can't have that." and then he'll be deaaaad." "I know! Let's give the niggers this music by a bunch of mumbling idiots-- Anthony takes his eyes off the road.

--and they'll all copy (chorus: ) it and sooner or later "In the home of the brave no one will be able to and the land of the freeeee. understand a fuckin' Gonna have black boys word they say! End of swinging, from each old problem!" oak treeeeee." BAM! They hit something. Both heads snap front, see nothing. They spin around to look behind them: nothing th either.

head_text.subj: THE DOOR OF THE PANEL VAN 23

text: A set of keys sway back and forth in the lock.
Anthony looks to Peter.
What the fuck was that? As Anthony stomps on the brakes...
The Navigator skids to a stop and they hop out. Peter loo under the fender and comes flying back up.
Holy shit, we run over a Chinaman!
You're saying there's a Chinaman under this truck? (CONTINUED)
What do you not understand? There's a Chinaman stuck under the goddamn truck! Anthony bends down, looks right into the bleeding face of the Korean man. Anthony pops up like he's just been shot.
Where the hell did he come from?!
Fuckin' China! What do you mean where'd he come from?!
He was standing in the street?
No, I think he comes with the truck, Anthony! It's an option now, for people who don't want to go through all the trouble of running over their own fucking Buddhahead!
What the hell he do, leap out in front of the truck?
I don't know, maybe the FBI planted him under there to make car-jacking black people look bad in the eyes of the larger community. You got a theory about that, too?
This is so completely fucked.
Help me.
Shut up! I'm trying to think! (paces) Fuck-fuck-fuck! Okay, come on, get back in the truck.
What? You think we didn't drag him far enough?! (CONTINUED)
We'll drive away, he'll let go.
He's not gonna let go! He's stuck under the fucking truck! If he coulda let go, he probably would have considered that option half a block back! Just grab his arm, we'll pull him outta there.
You grab his arm it's gonna fall off! You're gonna be standing in the street holding a Chinaman's arm. Then what you gonna do?
We leave him there, the man dies, and we're up on murder charges, Einstein. Now grab his goddamn arm! Anthony relents. They reach under and as Choi screams...
Christine drops her purse and snatches up the phone.
Who are you calling?
I'm gonna report their asses. Sons of bitches..
And you actually think they're going to take you seriously?
(slams phone down) Do you have any idea what that was like to have that pig's hands all over me? And you watch him do it and then you apologize to him?? What the fuck was that about?
What did you want me to do, get us both shot? (CONTINUED)
--They were gonna shoot us on Ventura Blvd??
So, you would have been satisfied with just being arrested.
You're right, Cam, much better to let him shove his hand up my crotch than get your name in the paper.
Yeah, that's what I was worried about.
It wasn't? You weren't afraid all your good friends at the studio were gonna read about you in the morning and realize you were actually black?
You need to calm down here.
No, what I need is a husband who won't just stand there while I'm being molested!
They were cops! They had guns! Where do you think you're living, with mommy and daddy in Greenwich?
--Go to hell.
Maybe I shoulda let them lock your ass up. I guess sooner or later you should learn what it's like to be black.
Fuck you, like you know. Closest you ever came to being black was watching the Cosby Show. (CONTINUED)
At least I wasn't watching it with the rest of the equestrian team.

You know, you're right, Cam, I got a lot to learn. 'Cause I haven't quite learned how to shuck and jive. Let me hear it again: "Thank you, Mr. Poh-liceman. You sure is kind to us po' black folk. You be sure to let me know next time you wanna finger-fuck my wife."
You know what? Fuck you.
Oh that's good. A little anger. A bit late, but nice to see. He slams out of the room.
Jean's feet descend the stairs to the expansive kitchen, where DANIEL, the Hispanic locksmith, re-keys the door. He's twentyish, close-cropped hair, baggy pants, tattoos.
How much longer are you going to be?
This is the last door.
Thanks. She exits, walking through the butler's pantry into the d room, where several staff members work. She turns into th living room, where Rick and two aides work up strategy.
Nothing from Parker Center.
(interrupting) I need to talk to you. (CONTINUED)
She exits without waiting for a response. Rick turns to KAREN, his top aide (young, black, brilliant), who is on Trio, laptop in front of her.
Just find Flanagan. Karen dials as Rick exits to the...
where Jean waits, arms crossed so tightly they're squeezi all the air out of her lungs.
I want the locks changed again in the morning.
Honey, why don't you go bed. Did you check on James?
Of course I checked on James, I've checked him every five minutes since we've been home, don't patronize me! I want the locks changed again in the morning!
Shhh, it's okay. You just need to lie down.
Didn't I just ask you not to treat me like a child?
Sorry, Mrs. Jean... It's MARIA, their Salvadoran housekeeper and babysitter, sweater and bag in her arm.
Yes, Maria? Jean turns away, livid.
Is okay I leave now? (CONTINUED)
Yeah, sure, thanks for staying.
No problem. Good-night, Mrs. Jean.
Good-night. Maria exits. Jean speaks to Rick as if English is his sec language:
I want the locks changed again in the morning.
Jean--
And you could mention that we'd appreciate it if next time they didn't send a gang member.
(lowering his voice) ..-You're talking about that kid in there?
Shaved head, pants down around his ass, prison tattoos?
Oh for Christ sakes, those aren't prison tattoos!
Right, and he isn't going to sell our key to one of his gang-banger friends the moment he's out the door.
Jean, it's been a tough night. Why don't you go upstairs and--
--wait for them to break in? (now in a rage) I just had a gun pointed in my face! (CONTINUED)
(sotto) Lower your voice!

--And it's my fault, because I knew it was going to happen! But if a white person sees two black men walking toward them and turns and walks the other way, she's a racist, right? Well, I got scared and I didn't say anything and ten seconds later I had a gun in my face! Now I'm telling you that your amigo in there is going to sell our house key to one of his homies! And this time it'd be really fucking nice if you acted like you actually cared!! Jean turns and storms into the kitchen. Rick stares at he as she makes a show of wiping down the counter.
throws a look over her shoulder toward the backdoor, sees
packing up his tools, looking right back at her.
looks away and busies herself with the dishes.
turns and walks back to the...
BRUCE, his second aide, works on a way to spin this. Kare snaps her cell phone closed and turns to Rick.
Flanagan doesn't think anyone has the story yet.
Flanagan's an idiot. We're talking minutes. (CONTINUED)
I've called a friend at KCBS--

--Bruce, you can call God himself: I'm the fucking District Attorney! I get my car jacked, it's gonna make the news. Christ, why did they have to be black?! No matter how we spin this I'm gonna either lose the black vote or the fucking law and order vote. I got West Side Jews up the ass; aren't there any Hasidic kids going bad?
Do you have to say they were black?
You're right, Bruce, I should have told my own cops that I couldn't quite make out the color of two men standing less than a foot from me. Give yourself a raise.
I think you're worrying too much. You have a lot support in the black community.
So did Gil Garcetti. Remember him? Former DA, tall guy, had that little run-in with oJ?
They stole your car at gunpoint in the middle of Westwood!

Check the LA Weekly tomorrow, I'll be the one with the gun in my hand. Tf we can't duck this thing we have to neutralize it. You know what I need? I need a black man I can pin a medal on. I need a picture of me pinning a medal on a fucking black man. What about that fire fighter who saved those campers in-- (CONTINUED)
He's Iraqi.
He's Iraqi? He looked black.
Iraqi. Saddam Khahum.
Saddam? You want me to pin a medal on an Iraqi named Saddam?? Are you out of your fucking mind? And Rick blows out of the room, as Bruce wonders why he e opens his mouth.

burst into the Jeep, enveloping them. Ryan cuts the belt loose. Suddenly, he's yanked out by the feet! He makes a grab for Christine.

sees him coming for her, reaches out. (CONTINUED)

pull and

pull Ryan and Christine away from the Jeep and toss a bla over them, smothering their smoldering clothing. In the background, the firemen arrive and attack the flames.

sits on the pavement, cradling Christine tightly in his a as she sobs. Christine looks up at him, sobbing, confused angry, grateful -- she searches his eyes for answers, som way to make sense of what just happened.

And cut. Cameron sits slumped in his director's chair. He says nothing. The A.D. looks to him with the implied question: are we printing or doing another? A battered white Honda pulls to the curb. On the seat is open phone book. Behind the wheel sits Farhad. He looks t the house across the street. A yellow school bus pulls up blocking his view. It honks its horn and drives away, and we see a couple kids disperse onto the sidewalk. One of them waves to the others; Lara, Daniel's daughter. Lara's mother meets her and walks her inside. There's no truck i the driveway. Farhad pulls the gun out from under the phone book, opens the cylinder and sees that it is loaded. He snaps it clos and shoves it back. And waits.
Karen shows Graham into a conference room the size of a bowling alley. Inside we find Bruce, answering his cell phone, and JAKE FLANAGAN, kingmaker and "Head of Media Relations."
The D.A. asked me to apologize, he wanted to be here himself. (CONTINUED)
(offers hand with a smile) No, he didn't. If he did his own dirty work, none of us would have jobs. Jake Flanagan, Media Relations. Bruce snaps shut his cell phone, to Flanagan:
He's just pulling into the garage.

The press conference is in ten minutes, so we'll make this short. (flips open file) Internal Affairs says this Conklin has two suspicious shootings on his record -- both black men, both times he was cleared but only just. Detective Lewis makes black man number three. You know any reason why we shouldn't hang Conklin for this?
It looks a little more complicated than we thought. We found over three hundred thousand dollars in the trunk of the car Lewis was driving.
Shit. (to Bruce) Get down to the garage, tell him to stay there until he hears from me. Bruce bolts for the door.
You found the money in the Mercedes? I thought that wasn't his car.
It's registered to a Cyndee Bradley, we haven't been able to speak to her, as she "left town" this morning.
So, it wasn't Lewis' car. He may not have even known the money was in it. (CONTINUED)
If you say so.
Latasha Harlins, Rodney King, these names ring a bell, Detective?
Yeah.

We have attorneys for this slain police officer camping in our offices. We have his mother and a half-dozen men of the cloth who swear that Lewis was one of the twelve apostles of Christ. We have two black city councilmen and a congresswoman who call every hour on the hour demanding to know what the District Attorney intends to do about this and you want him to walk into that press room and tell them all that the situation is "complicated"?? A moment of silence, then a decision.
(to Karen) Give us a minute. Karen stands, exits.
Who knows about the money?
You're kidding me, right?
There are only two people in this room.
(beat) Myself, my partner and Ferguson in Internal Affairs.
Jim Ferguson? (CONTINUED)
Yes.

(beat) Okay. I guess I don't see a problem here. As it wasn't Lewis' car, the money isn't clear evidence of any wrong-doing. Even if it was, we aren't going to prosecute a dead man. Which means the money that Internal Affairs is holding can't even be considered evidence.
Well, you can do this dance, but when the Coroner's report comes in tomorrow, my bet is it says Detective Lewis was coked out of his head.
Fucking black people, huh?
...I'm sorry?

I mean, I know all the sociological reasons why eighty percent of the men in prison in this state are black... schools are a disgrace, lack of opportunity, bias in the judicial system, all that stuff... but still it's gotta get to you, I mean on a gut level, as a black man. They just can't keep their hands out of the cookie jar. Graham laughs at this asshole.
Course you and I know that's not the truth, but that's the way it always plays, doesn't it. And assholes like Lewis just keep feeding the flames. It's got to get to you.
(beat) You coach ball down in Compton, am I right? (CONTINUED)
Don't try and pretend you know anything about me.

(opening a file) Oh, I know more than you think. (beat) What do you think those kids need? To make them believe; to give them hope? You think they need another greedy black asshole? Another drugdealing cop? Or do you think they need a fallen black hero?
If you're finished being the black man's best friend, you want to just tell me what I'm being offered here?

Oddly, the DA's squad is losing its lead investigator next month. Rick is quite adamant that his replacement be a person of color. It's a high profile position, and he wants to send the right message to the community.
And that message is what, look at the Black Boy I bought? Thanks for thinking of me.
Actually we were thinking of you until we saw this. Flanagan slides a piece of paper out of the file and acro the table toward Graham.

It's a warrant for your brother's arrest. Twenty-something years old and already his third felony. Three Strikes Law, kid's going away for life for stealing a car. Christ that's an unfair law. But still, he had every opportunity you had. Fucking black people, huh? (CONTINUED)
(beat) So, to make this disappear, all I have to do is frame an innocent man.

What are you, the fucking Defender of All Things White?! We're talking about a white man who shot three black men and you're arguing that maybe we're not being "fair" to him?! (beat) You know what, maybe you're right: maybe Lewis did provoke this. Maybe he got what was coming to him. Or maybe, stoned or not, just being a black man in the Valley was enough to get him killed. No one was there to see who shot first, so there is no way to know. Which means we could get this wrong. (re: warrant) Maybe that's what happened with your brother. Maybe we got it wrong. Maybe Lewis isn't the only one who deserves the benefit of the doubt. (beat) You're the one closest to all this. You need to tell us. What does your gut tell you? Graham looks to Flanagan and struggles with the decision.
Flanagan has disappeared. Reporters hover in the press ro at the far end of the hall. Down at this end Graham and Karen wait uncomfortably. The stairwell door opens and Ri approaches.
So, Graham. What do I tell them? You tell me, and I'll tell them.
...Given Detective Conklin's history...I'd say it's clear what happened last night.
Okay. (CONTINUED)

Rick nods and heads for the press room at the end of the hall. Karen hesitates, almost disappointed, then follows. Graham watches as Rick shakes hands with a couple of wait reporters and then disappears into the cavernous room. We hold on the open doors and push in.

Before I get to why we're here, I know you may have heard that we had our car stolen last night. As you can imagine, my wife is pretty shaken up, but we're both okay. And Jean and I appreciate the calls and your concern. (beat/fends off questions) Now. Just after nine p.m. last night, Detective William Lewis, an eight-year veteran of the force and an active member of the black community was gun-downed by a fellow officer. Bruce closes the doors.

The thick drapes are pulled tight, it looks like a cave i here. Graham stands in the kitchen, looking at his mother passed out cold on the sofa. The image breaks his heart. He pushes it out of his mind, turns and places the two Wh Foods bags down on the counter. He opens Louise's refrigerator and fills it with groceries.

turn from the intersection and head their way, red lights flashing.

You see what's happening here? You want to die here?! Is that what you want?? 'Cause these guys really want to shoot you, and the way you are acting they will be completely fucking justified.
Fuck you.
Step away from him!
(to Cameron) Fuck me? I'm not the one who is fucked here! You're the one who is fucked, 'cause you're the one who is gonna have his head blown across the street and onto that man's patio!
Officer Hansen, step away now!

(turns on them) He's a friend of mine, ok?! He's a fucking friend of mine! He is not armed and he is not gonna shoot me or anybody else! So give me two fucking seconds here! Stone and Hill share a look. Hill lowers his weapon and steps away, really pissed. Stone keeps the shotgun traine Hansen steps back to Cameron and speaks softly.
Are you starting to understand the situation here? (CONTINUED)

..-What the fuck you want?

Unless you think your wife is gonna be better off with a husband who has a bloody stump for a head, I want you to sit on that curb, put your hands on your head and do nothing until I speak to these officers.
I'm not putting my hands on my head or sitting on any fucking curb!
Then stand where you are and keep your hands in plain sight! Can you do that?
....Yeah.
(to other cops) I've told this man to stay where he is and keep his hands in plain sight. Hansen approaches Hill. Stone moves to join in the conversation.
This man better be related to you by blood, because this is fuckin' nuts.
--I need this favor. You can run his name and license -- there's no priors, no warrants. I need to let him go with a warning.
..-What kind of fucking warning?
A harsh warning. (CONTINUED)

Thanks. Hansen walks back to Cameron.

That I can do. Cameron turns, walks back to the Navigator, opens the doo and climbs in.
stares at him as if he is a patient from an insane asylum Cameron pulls shut his door. Cameron starts the engine as Hansen turns and walks back to the other cops.
You're writing this up. The cops get back into their cars as the Navigator pulls past them and cruises off.

You embarrass me. You embarrass yourself. For the first time in his life, Anthony's got nothing to say. He shoves his gun into his pocket and gets out, and the Navigator pulls away. He walks off down the sidewalk.

Give me LARA everything! I have it! He hasn't got his 'penetrable DANIEL cloak! You want the truck? It's not mine! Take it! Lara bolts out the door. Elizabeth chases after her.

Daniel doesn't see her coming until she's almost upon him leaping into his arms. Just as Farhad's finger jerks on t trigger....BANG! The bullet hits Lara straight in the bac

(in horror) (running) AHHHHH . Lara!l!!!! Daniel knows she is dead without even looking. The horror registers on his face -- and on Farhad's. But then, Daniel forgot something. Lara's wearing her impenetrable cloak. Which is why she's able to lift her head and look into his eyes.
It's okay, Daddy. I'11 protect you.

What? Daniel feels her back, no sign of a wound, no sign of a h this is impossible. Elizabeth is right there, throwing he arms around her daughter and husband. Farhad looks at his smoking gun. It falls to his side.
Baby! Farhad opens his mouth to apologize but can't say anythin Daniel just stares at Farhad, then walks his family towar his house.
(whispers in his ear) It's a really good cloak. He closes the door behind them. Leaving...
standing on the street, his mind reeling, neighbors stari
Hansen sits on the bench, changing his clothes with the r of the cops who are coming off shift. He nods to a passin black officer. (CONTINUED)

How's it going? The black officer just gives him a look and walks off out the door. Hansen looks around, sees the last few officers exit in their civvies, completely ignoring him. Now alone, Hansen leans back against the wall and watches the last drop of daylight disappear from the room. And suddenly he slams his locker closed.

Jean pads up the back stairs. She's wearing her workout clothes and a pair of sweat socks, the cordless phone to ear. She heads down the hall carrying a book and a stuffe animal. She drops off the animal in her son's room and ke walking under the following:

I sent her for groceries, that was two hours ago.... Carol, you should talk, you go through six housekeepers a year.... I'm not snapping at you, I'm just angry; I'm sorry.... (with growing agitation) Yes, at them! And the police and Rick and Maria and the dry cleaner who ruined another blouse and the gardener who keeps over-watering the lawn and.... (stops, grapples with an explanation) I just woke up this morning and I thought I'd feel better. You know? But I was still mad...and I realized : it wasn't about having my car stolen. That's how I wake up every morning....I'm angry all the time. (at the point of tears) And I don't know why. Carol, I don't know why. (beat/listens) Yeah, call me back. She hangs up the phone and heads for the front stairs. He foot slips on the top step and she falls.  105 106 107 108 109 3/18/04

Back in his civilian clothes, Ryan cruises up to a stop 1 in a dark part of town. The traffic light turns green, bu Ryan doesn't notice, lost in his thoughts. The car behind him lays on the horn and he takes notice and pulls out.

A dark patch in the road that twists through the oil fiel not a car in sight. Peter shoves his hands in his jacket pocket, feels something, comes out with the gun. heading in his direction. And...

Hansen drives home, barely listening to the country and western song that plays softly on the radio, his mind on night's events. He passes a hitch-hiker but thinks nothing of it, just an black kid. My hand to God. We notice Hansen is tapping his left leg double time to t music, a little too fast. The adrenaline is still pumping through him, and he's fighting it.
That's some rhythm you got working. Hansen gives him a sideways glance; pays a little more attention to his clothing now, particularly the small tea in his baggy coat.

Ice skating.

dust people, man.
People like me?

Take your hand out of your pocket!
Fuck you.

Oh God. Oh God. And it's obvious to both of them that Peter is going to d And Hansen reaches over for him, and supports his neck as Peter gurgles blood...and looks back at Hansen, dumfounde And while they look in each other's eyes, Peter dies. And Hansen panics.
Oh God. Oh no. Oh God. His mind racing, Hansen reaches over and opens the passen door...and Peter falls out.
The Crown Vic disappears into the distance, we tilt up to see the twinkling city lights below and FADE TO BLACK.
Hansen stares straight ahead, his mind gone numb.  3/18/04 101.
CRASH! Metal crunching, tires skidding, horns blaring. Then a long silence. Finally:
Heard it might snow.
Get outta here.
That's what I heard.
...What have you got?
Dead kid. We FADE UP to find:
Graham and Detective Carr at the crime scene. Graham walk down into the gully.
You touch anything and it's yours. Then Graham spots a SNEAKER in the grass, marked by an evidence flag. He looks up and sees something that makes his face turn to ash.

Anthony glances out the window at the shuttered stores an factories. He looks at the other occupants of the bus, an old black couple and three Hispanic housekeepers, laughin in the midst of an animated story. And he thinks "this is my fucking life." And looks back out the window. And sees something he recognizes. He yanks at the bell and stands.
They hang in the lock of the van door, exactly as we last saw them. Anthony's hand reaches in and turns them. (CONTINUED )

head_text.subj: REVEAL ANTHONY AND "THE CHINAMAN'S" PANEL VAN

text: Anthony climbs in, turns the engine over and drives off d the deserted street. Smiles.
Kim Lee, the Korean Woman who rear-ended Ria, frantically searches the rooms on either side of the hospital corrido
Choi Jin Gui! Choi Jin Gui! A NURSE steps out into her path, stops her.
Can I help you?
Choi Jin Gui! Choi Jin Gui!
Do you speak English?
I am speak English, you stupid cow! My husband name Choi Jin Gui!
The nurse opens the door and Kim Lee bursts in, hysterica
Jin Gui! Oh God, Jin Gui!
Ma'am-- The nurse gives up and exits and Kim Lee runs to her husb bed and throws her arms around him. Choi, "The Chinaman," his body bandaged and cast, sees her through drug-heavy e
...Kim Lee?
(in Korean) I thought you were dead -- I called every hospital. (CONTINUED)
It's okay, I'm okay. She kisses him repeatedly, as if barely believing he is a
I went crazy, speeding. I drove into a car.
Oh my God, are you all right?
(nods, then...) Got in big fight with poor woman. Call her names. He laughs through the pain.
Oh fine, I die from worry, you laugh.
(squeezes her hand) Thank you...for finding me. She smiles through tears.
Will you do something for me?
Anything.
Go to the locker. She walks to the four lockers that line the entrance to t ward.
The next one. She finds it, opens it.
In my shirt pocket. She reaches in, pulls out a check -- the company check th the other Korean man gave him in the deli. (CONTINUED)
Bring it here. She does. He motions her to lean close. He folds it into her hand and whispers into her ear.
(in Korean) Cash it right away.

RIA walks slowly along the corridor. Covered bodies on gurneys line the wall, overflow from the crowded morgue. She braces herself, then turns and looks back down the corridor, to see.... GRAHAM AND LOUISE standing further down the hall in front one particular gurney. The female coroner tech flips back the sheet enough for them to see. Louise's legs buckle. Her face contorts, her mouth opens, no sound able to esca RIA turns away, unable to watch as... THE PATHOLOGIST covers the body, offers a sympathetic loo and exits. As she gets closer we realize that she is Dorr Farhad's daughter. She approaches the wall phone in the hall, it's hold light flashing. She answers it quietly.
Hello?
Graham and Ria lower Louise onto a bench.
My baby, my poor baby. Ria walks to the nearby dispenser to get Louise some wate Graham, his face tear-stained, kneels beside his mother.
Shh. It's ok. Shhhh. I promise you. I promise you I'll find out who did this to him.
I already know. Graham looks back, confused. (CONTINUED)
You did. His mind reels as he tries to grasp her meaning.
I asked you to find your brother. But you were busy. We weren't much good to you anymore, were we? As her meaning stabs him in the heart...
You got things to do. You go ahead, I'll sign the papers.
-Ma?
I just want to wait with my baby. Graham gets to his feet and somehow finds the strength to walk down the hall.

He came home. You know that? My little boy. When I was sleeping. He brought me groceries. Last thing he did. Graham nods, turns and walks past Ria, barely looking at her. Ria watches him go, her heart breaking for them.
Anthony talks to Lucien. We see the van parked in b.g.
No, I get it; when I said "get me a black Lincoln Navigator", you thought I said "get me a white piece of shit panel van."
Just give me whatever. Georgie opens the back doors.
Lucien? You should see this. (CONTINUED)
Lucien and Anthony step to the rear of the panel van, loo in to see:

head_text.subj: A DOZEN OR SO ILLEGAL ALIENS

text: All Asian; incredibly thin, scared, their clothes filthy urine drenched, chained together, men, women and children the chain locked to the van with a padlock. Lucien and Anthony are speechless. Until...
I'll take the van.
They're chained to the van.
So, I'll take them, too.
You want to buy these Chinamen?
Don't be ignorant. They're Thai or something; entirely different kinda chinks. How much you want for them? Georgie, count ‘em up. As Georgie counts:
What the hell you gonna do with them?
Sell ‘em, what the hell you think? I'll give you five hundred a piece and you can keep the van. Anthony looks at the Illegals and...
Mister Rick?
Rick shuffles the papers under his arm as as he strains t hear his cell phone.
Maria? What's wrong?  3/18/04 107.
Mrs. Jean needs to talk to you. Maria hands the phone to Jean, who sits in bed, her ankle taped and propped on a pillow.
Rick?
What's wrong?
I fell on the stairs. He pushes the elevator button.
Are you okay?
When I couldn't reach you I called everyone; Julie and Marg and Suz....
(checks his watch/shit) I'm leaving right now.
It's okay, Maria drove me; it's just a bad sprain. I couldn't get through to anyone. Carol was the only one home. She said she couldn't come, she was having a massage. She's been my friend ten years.
The bitch. You okay?
Yeah, I'm okay.
Karen steps up beside him at the elevators.
I'm on my way. (CONTINUED)
Okay. A brief look passes from Rick to Karen: it's not going to happen tonight. She understands. The elevator doors open.
Jean puts the phone back on the cradle as Maria returns w a cup of tea.

You want to sit up? Jean nods. Maria puts the cup down. She wraps her arms around Jean's shoulders and pulls her up so that Jean's leaning against the headboard. Maria goes to move away, b Jean holds on. Her eyes are tearing up.

You want to hear something funny?... You're the best friend I have. Maria rubs her back as Jean holds on tight. INT. THE CHINAMAN'S PANEL VAN -- NIGHT 11%. Anthony drives alone in the night, through a desolate par of town. A slim hand reaches through the chain-link divid behind the seat, the fingers touch his head. Anthony jerk his head away. Another tiny hand reaches out and touches his ear. Anthony swats it away. A third hand reaches to touch his head, then a fourth, a fifth. Anthony tries to ignore them now, just keeps his eyes on the road and driv into the night. Suddenly his face is lit by a distant fireball reaching into the sky. Anthony turns and looks across the distant dirt field.

As the fireball settles, the flames consume a 1993 shit-b Crown Victoria. Hansen tosses a gas can into the field an walks away, silhouetted by the flames. He peels off his work gloves and stuffs them in his pocket. When we finall see his face clearly we can tell he is a man destroyed, l no idea how he got here.
Dark, save for the moonlight filtering through the window The glass door opens, Dorri enters. (CONTINUED)

The headlights of a passing car reveal Farhad sitting alo in the empty market, the gun in his hand, his face ashen strained. Dorri crosses to her father, squats before him. He looks into her eyes, tries to find the words, can't. She stares down at the gun, fearing the worst.
What did you do? (no answer) Dad, what did you do?
I shot a little girl. Dorri gasps.
She's fine. She isn't hurt. I was this far from her, I shot her in the back.
Oh my god.
(in Farsi) She was my firishta.
What are you talking about?
My firishta. You don't know your faith. She was my angel. She saved me. She saved us all. (offers her the gun) Take it. Please. Dorri takes it.

Dorri opens the hidden compartment, looks in to see the r box of ammo she placed there. For the first time we're cl enough to read the label: .32 SMITH & WESSON BLANK Black Powder BLANKS. She slips the box into her purse, checking to see if her father noticed.  120 121 122 123 124 3/18/04
Cameron drives, staring ahead. through the windshield.
Snow falls all around the car. lot on the corner just ahead.
doesn't know what the hell he's car.

Cameron gets out, marvelling at him. He touches a flake on his black. Ash. black kids who should be in bed the car fire, table, having a heck of a time, them. He crosses the street, throwing junk in - cardboard boxes, 110. 126

Suddenly he notices something A fire burns in the vacant looking at. He stops the 121 the "snow" falling all around white shirt it smears to where a half a dozen all dance and play around an old as ash rains down all around Cameron joins them, watching the Crown Victoria burn, wat the kids laugh and chase each other. He smiles to himself. His cell phone rings. He checks the readout: HOME.
Looking in through their window we see Christine sitting the bed in the dark, wearing her sweats, hair wet, lookin scraped and worse for the wear, phone to her ear.
Staring at the readout. He finally makes the decision and presses TALK.
(tenderly) Hi.
Almost cries.
Watches the boys play. One of them tosses a broken chair the fire. Cameron smiles.
brushes away the tears that fall.

Looking in from outside we see Ryan, hands bandaged, help his frail and aging father into the bathroom. After some difficulty he eases him down onto the toilet. Where his father weeps. No apparent reason, just weeps. And Ryan kisses his forehead and holds him.
Lara sleeps in her parents' bed, nestled close to her mot Daniel stands at the window, looking out into the night.. wondering if that bullet is still out there somewhere.

Rick locks the kitchen door, the lock we saw Daniel repla Something makes him unlock it and lock it again. And then he slowly looks up, at the darkness of the yard beyond. A he stands there, unable to move, now finally alone, all h fears washing over him.
All that's left is the crime scene tape. Graham stands al in the headlights of his own car. He fingers the cracked St. Christopher statuette in his hand, then stares out in the long grass; lost.

The streets are busy, but most people just hurry on their way. The Chinaman's panel van pulls to a stop, a couple cars back from the light. Anthony looks around, sees all the Chinese. He puts the v in park, yanks the keys out of the ignition and walks aro back. He flings open the back door of the van, stuffs a key in padlock and pulls out the chain. The chain slips through the metal cuffs on their ankles. (CONTINUED)
The Illegals stare at him, unmoving. : Anthony yells at them:
Pull ‘em off! He pries open one of the anklets to show them how. The ot kids follow his example.
Come on-come on-come on, this is America, time is money. One of the kids steps out of the van, then another.

Chop-chop, let's go. And from there, two dozen wide-eyed Illegals step out int the street and get their first real look at America. They weave off through traffic, and down the crowded sidewalk. ONE stops at a fruit and vegetable stand, marvelling at t variety of produce -- pokes something strange. ANOTHER TWO step out of the van and find the fish market they laugh and finger the fish on ice. The MARKET OWNER rushes out of his store YELLING in CHINE and shooing them away. ANOTHER COUPLE stop at the store displaying bins of CD's and push a stack back and forth like dominoes. A FRIGHTENED man squats on the sidewalk, his back to a sh wall, watches the passing faces, nodding hellos to strang who ignore him. A WOMAN walks, stunned and awed by the signs above her, b jostled and bumped by stern-faced pedestrians.
An impatient driver behind the van lays on the horn. The last few Illegal climbs out of the van. Anthony stuffs a couple twenties in one man's hand.
You split that up. Buy everybody chop-suey, you understand? (CONTINUED)
The man walks off into the street.
Dopey fucking Chinamen. Anthony closes the back door, climbs back into the van an drives off. As he disappears around the corner
brakes hard in the extreme foreground and is immediately REAR ENDED.
of the first car climbs out. It's Shaniqua.
What in the hell is wrong with you people? The two HISPANIC OCCUPANTS of the second car step out and argue with her in Spanish.
Don't talk to me unless you can speak American. A CHINESE STORE OWNER decides to set her straight.

(to store owner) You mind your own business and -- (to Hispanic Driver) You show me your insurance. (more argument) Don't pretend you don't know what I'm talking about: the word starts with the letters I-N-S, which is who I'm gonna call if you don't hand it over pronto. And as we rise we see the twisted chaos of the intersecti the cars and the people and the Illegals disappearing int the maw of the churning city. And it starts to snow.
